dialogues.text: (volce slurred) No, Damien... But Damien keeps on looking at him, his eyes blazing, and soon there is a trickle of blood coming from Teddy's nose, and his eyes are closing, as though he has been bludgeoned, and he half-slumps against a wall, barely hel on his feet.

dialogues.text: Damien...? Damien wrenches his head to one side, pulling his gaze fr Teddy, who begins weeping, running away. All are staring. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eT 25 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: (voice hollow) Foster next... He starts walking, afraid of himself, not knowing what ha happened.

dialogues.text: Damien'and Mark come out onto the playing fields.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What did you do to him...?

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: I don't know... He shakes his head in confusion, then grins and starts running. Mark follows.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They've asked me to join the band.

dialogues.speaker: DAMIEN
dialogues.text: That's great. Once around the field -- give you a head start! They run off into the distance. INT. THORNSâ€™ COUNTRY HOUSE ~ HALLWAY/FAMILY 26

dialogues.text: MAIDS and other domestics are shaking out voluminous whit dust-covers and placing them over furniture. It's a sad, almost macabre sight -- a mixture of museum and mortuary! Ann climbs the marble stairs.

dialogues.text: MAIDS are collecting dirty bed linen from bedrooms. Ann rounds corner,

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: (to Maid) Is Miss Marion dressed yet, Jennie?

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: I don't think she's awake yet, Mrs. Thorn. I knocked earlier, but she didn't answer.

dialogues.text: _ CAMERA MOVES WITH Ann as she crosses to the bed --

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (trying for friendliness ) Aunt Marion --? SLOWLY Ann and CAMERA APPROACH the bed --~

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: You don't want to miss your flight -- And she stops, looking down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: who lies under the sheets, eyes open and staring, mouth agape, the BIBLE open on her chest.

dialogues.text: â€˜ e (passionately) Bill, you're wrong. My report points to the indisputable fact that Thorn Industries! main interest is in energy and electronics. dialogues.speaker: ATHERTON
dialogues.text: (containing anger) That statement is typical of you, Paul. It's heartless and...

dialogues.text: True! Not heartless, realistic. They continue in silence, humming past the massive contro . console. Operating TECHNICIAN swivels in his chair to w them pass. Richard points at the vats.

dialogues.text: \ e {to Panchali) What are in those?

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: (to Atherton) One person dies of starvation every 8.6 seconds. 7 every minute. 420 every hour. 10,000 every day. His voice recedes as the buggy moves further away. Teleph on console rings.

dialogues.text: (into receiver) Dryhurst. (pause) Mr. Thorn?

Cont. 518  30 30 Cont.1 TECHNICIAN (Cont. ) (looks at the receding buggy -- now a speck in the distance) He just went by. (pause) Ten seconds ago. (pause) How would I know? He hangs up and returns to his book.

dialogues.text: Boxes of green shoots as far as the eye can see. Above th we see Buher, Panchali, Atherton and Richard walking ancl talking:

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: -+-the oil countries didn't hesitate to put their fingers on our jugular vein, So, what's so different about food? (smiles) If there's a knife at your belly, you'll keep your hands at your side. Why then call my poicy unethical? TECHNICIAN'S white coat has approached.

dialogues.text: You're wanted on the telephone, Mr. Thorn. It's urgent. Richard quickly follows him.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (into receiver) Yes. (listens) Oh, no! (pause) Jim's looked at her? pause) I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buher and Atherton are still locked in battle. Panchali. intervenes. Cont. 518  518 31 32 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill's point is that if we control the food people eat, it's tantamount to making slaves of them.

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: (quietly) Customers.

dialogues.speaker: ATHERTON
dialogues.text: But you want us to buy up their land.

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: That's right, Thorns already have the hardware and knowledge that's easily adaptable to the purpose of highly sophisticated farming. This, together with the pesticides ana fertilizers we're producing...

dialogues.speaker: ATHERTON
dialogues.text: (interrupting) If we control their land, we make them tenants!

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: We make their bellies FULL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to agree with Paul. Richard joins them.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Marion died in her sleep last night. A coronary.

dialogues.speaker: ATHERTON
dialogues.text: I am sorry!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I must go. (to Buher) Can we have breakfast tomorrow? At the office.

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (to Atherton) I'll speak to you later, Bill. Cont.  32 32 Cont.1 He heads off at a-fast pace.

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: Have they moved into the apartment yet?

dialogues.speaker: ATHERTON
dialogues.text: Today.

dialogues.speaker: BUHRER
dialogues.text: (sadly) Winter's here again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THORNS' COUNTRY MANSION
dialogues.text: Staff are loading suitcases into station wagons. Hearse waits in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every piece of furniture is now shrouded in white dust sheets. Shafts of winter sun cut across the spacious entrance hall and reception rooms. Funeral directors move slowly down the staircase carrying Marion's stretcher. Murray puts down the remaining suitcases as they pass out the door. Richard and Ann follow the coffin out. Ann takes his arm, whispering in his ear:

dialogues.speaker: . ANN
dialogues.text: I love you. I hope we go together. Murray picks up the suitcases and leaves, closing the doo The house is silent, empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is ABOVE the low clouds clamped over the city. Onl the tops of the skyscrapers are visible, giving the place an unearthly quality. CAMERA ZOOMS ACROSS the dark rollin vapors to Thorn Industries Headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: INT, DIRECTORS' DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Richard and Buher are having breakfast. Both are spooning up grapefruit, and a Butler is bringing in soft~boiled eg Conversation is casual for a moment --

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: When will you open the exhibit?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It has a lot to do with when the last of the crates arrive from abroad... but plans are for Easter. Cont.  33 36 Cont. The Butler removes grapefruit, exits.. Richard and Buhev crack open the eggs in silence. Then, quietly, but bus:ne like --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I've made a decision concerning your report --

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: (sensing rejection, quickly Let me ease your mind about that --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I've come down on Bill Atherton's side. Richard looks at him, and Buher bends to his egg, talking calmly, as though it's no pain to him to have been turned down.

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: . Yes, it might be premature for the company to embark on such a radical ~ program; I wouldn't want to risk defusing it before its time. All right...let's keep it on ice.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: (quietly) Richard, if you think I went too far... if Bill's antagonism towards me is going to continue -- maybe I should step down. Leave the company...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Forget it. (friendly smile) Your time'li come.

dialogues.text: Richard and Buher come out of the building, pull up their coat collars against the blustery day, They shake hands -

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You'll be coming to Mark's birthday party?

dialogues.speaker: BUHER
dialogues.text: Of course. Lake be frozen yet? 518 Cont.  518 34 37 Cont.

dialogues.text: (smiles, claps Buher's arm) Bring your skates. He starts away towards his car. Murray opens door. Buher waves, and heads for his own car parked nearby.

dialogues.text: as Richard starts to duck into his car -~-

dialogues.text: Morning, Murray, that's a cold wind.

dialogues.text: (o.8.) Mr. Thorn! Thorn stops, looks back. Murray looks, too. CAMERA PANS AND ZOOMS to JOAN HART, in her thirties, bundled up again the cold, wearing boots and gloves, and carrying a big leather bag over one shoulder. dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Sorry to shout at you like that, I didn't want to miss you...

dialogues.text: (politely) That's all right, what --

dialogues.text: My name's Joan Hart. I think Charles Warren told you about me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes, he did. I asked him to --

dialogues.text: It's absolutely freezing, couldn't we possibly sit in your car while you tell me why you won't let me interview you? Cont.  35 38-A Cont.

dialogues.text: (has to smile) Get in. Joan ducks into the car, Richard gets in after her, and Murray closes the door, then gets into the front -~-

dialogues.text: Joan dives into her bag, brings out a handkerchief, gives her nose a good blow --

dialogues.text: Miss Hart --

dialogues.text: I know. You hardly ever talk to reporters and...

dialogues.text: -- two minutes. That's all.

dialogues.text: I'll come to the airport with you. Where are you going? Richard leans forward, opens the window between himself a Murray --

dialogues.text: (smiling) Advising the President on how to run the country? Cont. 518  518 36 39 Cont.

dialogues.text: (smiling back) No. dust the Secretary of State. Now, what can I possibly tell you?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (scribbling in her pad) Â».-what did it cost your father to build your museum in -- {consults a note) ~- 1904, wasn't it?

dialogues.text: (big smile) Makes the world go around, doesn't it?

dialogues.text: That, and a few other things. (sighs) I think it cost him around ten million.

dialogues.text: When he came to Chicago, didn't he start work in the stockyards -- ?

dialogues.text: And didn't he make you and your brother Robert take cold baths and sleep rough, so you'd know what it was like to be poor? Cont.  518 37 40 Cont. Richard looks at her and laughs --

dialogues.text: Never. EXT. CHICAGO ~ DAY 4a â€œCar approaching bridge over the Illinois River as red li begin to flash and strident bells warn the traffic to hal A barricade is lowered and the massive bridge begins to r

dialogues.text: (finishes writin, something in pad Did you ever meet the archaeologist Carl Bugenhagen?

dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.text: Did you know he was also an exorcist?

dialogues.text: (turns to look at her) itd heard...

dialogues.text: Â«Â»-how do you know?

dialogues.text: (leans forward, anger rising) Murray, stop the car --

dialogues.text: Get out --

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Do you know why your brother went to see him --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don't make me throw you out, Miss Hart --

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Please, listen to me. I've been working on the story for years! I think I've pieced Lt together -~ Murray has got out of the car, and is coming around to Jo open door --

dialogues.text: I didn't believe before, I was never religious -- but now <= Cont. 518  39 42 Cont.1 Murray reaches in and takes her arm. As he firmly pulls h out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Youfre in grave danger!

dialogues.text: Don't ever come near me again! Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: J
dialogues.text: Turn to Christ!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Murray i Murray slams the door shut, and prods Joan away. She shouts --

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Only He can protect youl Murray runs around to the driver's seat, jumps in. Joan rushes up to the car, bangs on the back window --

dialogues.speaker: JOAN

So that nobody can miss it, we're putting it right here in the middle of Room Four,

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (Laughing) I think you should lean her against one of the back doors! Joan approaches them, Warren sees her.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: (surprised) Joan! When did you get in?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Last night. Cont.  518 Warren turns to Ann.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: Ann, this is Joan Hart. â€˜

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Yes...I saw her in the photograph Â«Â»-beside the Whore of Babylon! They shake hands,

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Ann Thorn,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gather your husband hasn't a very high opinion of journalists?

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: He has this thing about them living off others' misfortunes.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Like Jackals?

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: 46 cont. Warren's pocket bleeper calls him. Relieved -- he switche it off and nervously moves away.

dialogues.text: Back in a moment. He goes to an internal telephone. Ann and Joan face each other.

dialogues.text: Your husband is a little unfair on the Press. They were very kind to his brother. Cont.  4e 46 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (sharply) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: . JOAN
dialogues.text: Their reporting of his death was most circumspect. After all, the circumstances were a little unusual.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: (calm under pressure) Were they? I never knew his brother,

dialogues.text: You should be writing for the Woman's Page.

dialogues.text: You've made a fool of me. Richard's furious.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You're in danger -- all of you -- |

dialogues.text: What's got into you? Cont. 518  518 43 46 cont.2

dialogues.text: I've seen the Yigael's wall.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: I don't care what you've seen!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (persistent) You must care. Damien -~

dialogues.speaker: . WARREN
dialogues.text: What about him? Long pause. Joan is deeply disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure yet. She breaks away and runs off. Warren watches her, then turns back to Ann.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: No idea...

dialogues.text: Thorn! Damien's eyes never leave her until she reaches the car.

Sudden wintery wind moans and whips the few trees into movement. The confident sound of the car's engine continues, then suddenly falters. The vehicle slows to a halt as the engine cuts out altogether, Wind drops as suddenly as it blew up, leaving an eerie silence. Car's ignition is | turned but fails to bring any life to the engine. Again and again the key is turned in frustration. INT. CAR - LATE AFTERNOON 4g Joan stops trying to start the car. She's very agitated. The fuel gauge shows the tank to be half-full. She looks up the road ~- not a sign of life. She looks through the rear window. It's equally bleak. Near the car, however, she sees a billboard advertising a restaurant "3 miles" along the road, Nervous, she switches on the car radio, punching up the different stations in frustration. One catches her ear. A rabid preacher frightening the life ou of his listeners:

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: (voice over) Â«Â»-for He was oppressed and he was afflicted, yet He opened not His mouth; He is brought as a lamb to the slaughter... She SWITCHES IT OFF and sits, anxiously drumming her fing on the steering wheel and murmuring to herself:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Â«e-Who art in heaven. Hallowed be Thy name, Thy Kingdom come, Thy will be done... Cont.  oo) 49 Cont. Further glances up and down the road. No cars in sight. The billboard opposite again takes her attention. She get out of the car and leans across to the backseat for her coat. There's an abrupt fluttering sound followed by stra seratching on metal. She jumps back. There, by her face, a crow settles its enormous wings and eyes her from the ear roof. Joan gasps and moves instinctively away. The crow's nasty little eyes never leave her. She waves her coat ineffectually to frighten it away but the bird doesn move, Joan kicks the car door shut and moves off, watchin the crow as she pulls on her coat. Even with the gap wide ing between her and the car, she looks nervously back, Th crow just sits there, Twenty yards, Thirty. Forty. She takes a final look -- the crow has gone. Disquieted, she looks all around, The bird has disappeared, and with it g her anxieties. She settles down to cover the three miles without again looking back, CAMERA FOLLOWS her. â€˜There's an awful screech and the crow descends from behind, It crash-lands on her head and WE SEE it lean forward, yello beak open. When the poor, demented woman finally turns, WE SEE her eyes are gone from the bloody sockets. â€˜The crow's wings open wide and, like an avenged angel, it lifts off into the sk CAMERA RISES ABOVE the blinded woman reeling about the tarmac and finally slipping down the shoulder into a fiel Her screams and sobs float up unheeded.
